This is a clip for installation on top of the tool head of a TAZ printer.
It is for restraining one end of the filament guide tube to reduce strain of brittle filament (like cheap PLA) to keep it from snapping while printing.
You will need to first mark a hole to drill on the tool head using it as a template. Slowly drill the hole big enough for a heat-set copper insert (some times it is called push-in insert). I used an insert for M2.5 screw and the screw length I used was 16 mm.

You do need to drill a hole for a heat-set insert on the tool head (see photo on where that hole will be)
Use this piece as a template to mark the location of the hole using a small drill bit. Then use a drill bit of the appropriate size for your heat-set insert to drill about the depth needed for the insert. Then insert the heat-set insert flush and that will do it.

This is a collection of 11 different patches with icy/crystalshapes that fit together in shape and size.
I used them to make a part of a cosplay, but you can use it as decoration or basicaly everything you can think of. Every patch has the same basic size and is about 2.5x2.5 cm.
The big patches are about 5x5cm. You don't need support structures. (Form1)
I made everything with the tinkerCrystals fo my source and TinkerCAD

I made the models for a Form1 printer.
If you want it as shiny as mine or colored, do the following things: If printed with a Form1, use CLEAR resin If you want it really shiny and sparkling, use pearl acrylic colors (i.E. Lascaux), they are amazing for this kind of stuff and paint the downside only. To make sure it reflects incoming light as good as possible, take some aluminium foil or aluminium sticky tape and put the patches on it, you will see a difference immediately. To finish it, use shiny acrylic finish spray. For my cosplay I had to glue the patches on a base shape, if you are planning to do something similar, use hot glue and if you have extrem round shapes (like a bra), make sure you fill holes carefully with hot glue, to make sure it will hold.

title: Kitchen Towel Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple, yet much needed thing for your kitchen to free up some of that precious countertop workspace.  
Since I have some nice old screws lying around I originally designed the spool components to print in one piece without an axis, but to make this design available to anyone I also included a version that has a plastic axis and can be assembled using only glue and some bits of 1.75 mm filament.

Do NOT print all the STL files! You will only need 2. The wall mounts are required either way, but which of the other ones you will have to print depends on your choice of axis. A) You happen to have some 7 mm screws.
In this case, simply print "simple_towelholder-_7_mm_screw_required" and screw in the screws until you have the desired length sticking out to be used as the axis. Now stick the two parts into a roll of kitchen towel and use this whole assembly to determine how far away from each other the holes in the wall will have to be. B) You want to make an all-plastic version.
Print "simple_towelholder-_all_plastic". Align one of each part type so that the small holes are lined up. Now cut 5 pieces of 1.75 mm filament, each about 15 mm long and insert them into the corresponding holes, making sure they go all the way into the holes in the larger parts. This should be a tight fit, but I'd add a few drops of glue as well. Repeat for the other side.
Continue as in A) to mount it on the wall and you're done! :-)

author: mr_crawly1308

title: Mendel Max 3 Dual Extruder Dial Indicator mount

description.text:
So I finished putting together my Mendel Max 3 dual extruder 3D printer recently, and as usual I have a horrible time leveling the bed. As a result, I go and get a Dial Indicator from Harbor Freight, but unfortunately, there isn't an easy way to mount it on the print head. That's why I made this mount. It attaches to the DTI with a M5 screw and you slip it in between the two extruders on the front. It's not perfect, but good enough for my purposes. Let me know what you think.   
Update 3/16/2015: I have updated the design to what I consider is the final form. The previous versions wobbled while calibration was being performed, but that has since been fixed. I hope this design will be as useful to others as I have found it for myself. I have included 2 versions, one with and the other without supports.
I used ABS plastic with 15% infill and support pillars.

comments.text: This was a LIFESAVER.  I struggled for days to level my print bed and it wasn't until I stumbled on this that I had success.  Also, I appreciated the idea of the dial guage and got a great digital one at Harbor Freight for only $20.

Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5998 . Unfortunately, can not be made as-is. Hence the work-in-progress... This is an OpenSCAD design suitable for experimenting with a deltabot with various arm lengths. The main parameters (base width, arm length, animation toolpath etc) can be changed on the fly. It serves me as a test of both the coordinate transformation math and the resulting practical reach for a given arm configuration. Parts of it can be reused in other designs, for example the 3d line and toolpath rendering.

Load the design in OpenSCAD. It is completely self-contained.
Switch on View->Animation.
Fill in the framerate (20 FPS is a good start) and the number of frames (160 steps will result in clearly visible movement). Then start wondering whether this is a feasible 3d-printer design (all mechanics can be printed, it has a reach larger than the largest part) and whether an Arduino is fast enough to do the math.

description.text:
UK map jigsaw puzzle with two options for case though case is not must but it makes the life of little one easier. I suggest paste UK map sticker on printed jigsaw or do a paint (refer my india map jigsaw), color really make it look attractive.   
Also I recommend you print case1 and not case2 (refer instruction and picture for why i am saying so). If anybody got an idea to get it right please post it into comment.

map-case1 - printed using slic3r (dimension more or less same as map, i have used same as in stl) Layer Height = 0.25 (my head 0.5 mm) Vertical Shells > Perimeters Horizontal Shells > Solid Layer.Top=0 and Bottom=2 Infill > Fill density = 0 Note: Top = 0 & Fill density=0 makes it a hollow object For more details I suggest refer http://slic3r.org/blog Topic: Tip: printing vases Post Processing: Almost nil map-case2: First I made this and printed but have to spent lots of time in post processing, at last have cut the scotland into half to make it fit in the block. Issue is because there are many small curves/area. If we make the map boundary little smooth it will work. if you want to design your own map here are the instruction, http://indusmaker.blogspot.co.uk/2013/07/3d-printed-jigsaw-puzzle.html

Super simple, and cheap adapter to make a 4 meter long "selfie stick". Use a 6 meter fishing rod (telescopic) and remove the two thinnest sections. (I used this: http://www.biltema.se/sv/Fritid/Fiske/Spo-och-rulle/Metspo-45951/) Use the printed part and a 1/4 bolt of suitable length ( I cut mine with a dremmel). Use tape or Hot Glue (or epoxy) to fix the part to the fourth section. The inner diameter of the end of this section is roughly 14 mm. This will give you a versitile boom to mount anything (not heavy) with a 1/4 inch thread. I'm using it for a GoPro for shots from up high, and with a microphone as a boom microphone. If you want more stability I guess you can use only three sections, but then you need to modify the diameter (or use some tape). I'm using a fiberglass rod for very little money, but you could also use carbon fiber to increse stiffness, and you may need to change the diameter then as well.

Inspired by DIY Camera Guy:
https://www.youtube.com/user/DIYCameraGuy

description.text:
!SHIP NOT INCLUDED! :) There are lots of storage solutions for these tiny ships, but I wanted something that would allow me to carry just one ship (or a couple) rather than having to always take an entire box with me **LATEST UPDATES: 14/6/17 - I've uploaded the original Sketchup file for all these boxes. Feel free to use it as you see fit. So far I have included boxes for:
  • X-Wing (T-65)
  • A-Wing
  • Y-Wing
  • B-Wing
  • Tie Fighter (Should fit the TIE/FO too, but untested)
  • Tie Advanced
  • Tie Bomber
  • Tie Phantom
  • Z95 Headhunter
  • HWK 290
  • Scum Faction logos
  • Tie Interceptor
  • YT 2400 (Lid and box separate files)
  • YT 1300 (Lid and box separate files
  • Decimator (Lid and box separate files)
  • Firespray (Lid and box separate files)
  • Aggressor (Lid and box separate files)
  • TIE Defender
  • T-70 X-Wing
  • K-Wing
  • E-Wing
  • Phantom
  • Ghost (Lid and box separate files) - Added 9/9/16
  • Lambda Shuttle (Lid and box separate files) - Added 9/9/16
  • Punishing One (Lid and box separate files) - Added 9/9/16
  • Starviper - Added 9/9/16
  • Hounds Tooth (Lid and box separate files) - Added 9/9/16
  • Scyk - Added 9/9/16
  • TIE Punisher - Added 9/9/16
  • Mist Hunter - Added 9/9/16
  • Kihraxz- Added 9/9/16
    • “Will you be making a box for…” Probably, eventually, maybe. I have also created Pilot and Damage/Upgrade card boxes in the same style, you can find them here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755733

Print as placed, they should fit on any type of printer since they are pretty small. I use the following to print:
1.75mm PLA, .15 layer height, 0 perimeters, no supports/raft/brim should be necessary.

  • The Logos on the Lid:
    These are printed separately. Just glue them on afterwards (or not!)

  • The Hinge:
    You'll need a bit of 1.75mm filament for the hinge pin, I hold a lighter to the sticking-out-end of the filament once it's inserted into the hinge for about 1-2 seconds, then use a wet finger to push the hot end a little (be careful!) that'll be enough to make the filament bulge out and stop it sliding around (do this to both ends).
    • NOTE: After months of using this method, the hinges tend to break, the filament gets brittle and snaps. I now use 1.5mm steel wire, which is commonly sold in hardware/garden shops as bailing or fencing wire, that works great! You can also use a paperclip which apparently works well too! Apparently a paperclip also works nicely.

  • Finishing:
    The clip at the front is quite tight when first printed, it needs a bit of sanding/filing down (just a few seconds) to get it to a place that you're happy with. I like it to really grip the box so it's very hard to flip open, but you can just sand it down a little more to tune it to your needs.

  • Painting:
    Whatever you like! I used Acrylics airbrushed on for the box and the blaster-burns on the rebel boxes, and brush-painted the weathered red on the rebel logos. Then drybrused with silver. The imperial boxes are just airbrushed a flat gunmetal type grey.

comments.text: Out of curiosity, When using paperclips/steel wire, what do you use to make it stay in? (such as when using the filament you melt the end so it doesn't slide out but with metal)

comments.text: I use a dot of super glue. You can also use a piece of 1.75 filament :D

comments.author: Coltain

comments.text: Typically that is because you are not getting good layer adhesion.  You would need to calibrate your printer and your temps for your filament.  A "quick fix" would be to print the lids  vertically "on their edge" so the hinges and latch are up and down rather then flat on the print bed.  This makes them stronger so they can't "snap off". but will need support material to print.

RANT: As far as I'm concerned, Readytoflyquads owes me a refund for these garbage ESCs. Not a one ever saw use because they ALL FAILED. Every last piece of $#%# ESC that should never have been put on sale in the first place. I haven't ordered another thing from RTFQ and I don't intend to ever again.
This is a quick jig I made to keep some components in place when soldering these tiny ESCs. This was made for the 1.0 version (I think).  
I put some foil tape in the bottom of the jig to protect against heat and I used a piece of servo actuator rod to hold down those components that always move when you are trying to solder.  
Totally experimental; worked for me. (edit: but the ESCs were garbage anyway so don't waste your time)
Definitely print at 100% on 0.3mm

title: Spool holder brackets for M3D printer and 1/2" tubing

description.text: UPDATE: an updated and customizable version is available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:731318 . The newer version makes it easier to lift out the spool holder rod, so i suggest to use that instead The M3D printer has a built-in internal spool holder that has some limitations. I opted to simply mount the filament spools on top of the unit, above the extruder, and using the printer chassis as base. These are brackets only. Two sets are needed, one for each side, then simply add any dowel, rod or tubing of 1/2" OD (outer diameter) to complete this thing. The horizontal top tube needs to be 6" in length, but the vertical risers can be anything that make it tall enough to clear the printer and fit your spool size. Can fit multiple spools.

description.text: This is a 60 mm fan holder to cool off a 3D Printer Ramps. This holder is design to be mounted on aluminium extrusion. A deflector is also provided to prevent the air to go on the heated bed.

This is (another) printable pen holder for the Thing-O-Matic/Cupcake. I tried to bring at least something new to the party by stretching my artistic skills to the absolute limit for your enjoyment. UPDATE!!! 2011-3-20:
Youtube video of first gcode print...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NR3ZwVLx-xE
...would you say it's as fast as an F-14? Youtube video of (manual) test:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MEXvrOI0ZgY I wanted a pen mount so I could draw etch resist on PCBs. The existing mounts on Thingiverse are either not for a Makerbot: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3593 Mendel Pen Holder
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3526 Mendel Pen Spring Mount (oooh, springs!) Or were using a whole servo motor in the design (for something that's sitting on the Z platform!):
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4185 Makerbot's Unicorn Pen
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4200 Printable Unicorn Pen Or seemed like perfectly sane designs I should probably use but for my love of springs:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790 Updated Pen Plotter So with all that considered, I set out to reinvent the wheel. I'm still at it and what I've got is somewhat roundish, so I'm sharing it now. The "random" cat photo is one of my two cats, taken by a wonderful (and very patient!) photographer friend of mine. Her site is here: http://shutterboxing.com/ WIP WHY:
  • Needs redesign; too big - too tall.
  • Leg STL file has two right legs (so do my photos, I was anxious)
  • Front paws needed dremeling out to fit pen between.
  • Tail was a quick hack; I'd like to redo it completely.
  • Needs me to work with some existing pen plotting gcode generators to make them work OK. Only tests so far have been manual control, not Gcode.
  • As will be usual - I'll release the scad files AFTER I'm done with the STLs... I wish it weren't so as I believe strongly in release everything as early as possible, but Thingiverse stops rendering other files in a Thing after I send it an .scad. I might put it up on my github in the meantime...
    • UPDATE 2011-03-20: Added a copy of the Inkscape gcode plugin by Schmarty: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5986 The copy below in the .tgz is modified to include an option for "USE SERVO" which, if set false, will cause the gcode to use Z axis movements like in my video. UPDATE 2011-03-22: Added photos of first PCB attempt (it says 2011-02 because I dunno what month it is)! Needs some work, but it's actually useable, so that's great for a very first try. Here's a youtube:
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rAaGFV45_aM

Instructions:
  • Don't do anything yet unless you just think this design is already the coolest thing ever, 'cause I'm actively working on making it better. If you really want it now, then:
    • HARDWARE: I used a handful of the M3x40 and M3x25 bolts I had around, as well as two M5x30(ish) I got at the hardware store.
    Plus two springs.
    And some matching nuts. ASSEMBLY: I think you can figure it out from the photos and the hardware list. I'll get more detailed as the plan is more final.

comments.text: The unicorn was originally designed for the Cupcake which has a painfully slow Z stage, but now that there is the ToM with a super fast lead screw, I think there is probably no need for the servo. If you adjust your pen holder correctly and have a level platform then you only have to move the Z stage a fraction of a mm anyway. I think the servo is overkill for the ToM and only mildly overkill for the Cupcake. I tried changing the unicorn scripts to have a z move instead of a servo move. Its a really simple code mod. You only have to change it in like 5 places or something. I did the one that does pictures and that worked really well but was really slow on a Cupcake. I mean not so slow that its unusable, it just took like half an hour to draw a QR code. And that was with an unlevel platform and with a huge Z move (a few mm's). Hope this helps!

remixed_from.title: RepRapDiscount Smart LCD Controller Support for Prusa i3

description.text:
Our Prusa i3 takes many of the Prusa i3 Print enhancing upgrades available and combines them into one complete printer. These upgrades include:
  • Z-Axis Isolators (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:139857)
  • Touch Nozzle Bed Homing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:273805)
  • Z-Axis Framebrace (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:186640)
  • Belt Tensioners
  • LCD Smart Cover (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:85644)
    Any many other little upgrades...
    • The Z-Axis Isolators significantly improve layer alignment and print quality, especially at the finer layers. Combining the isolators with a mechanical endstop allows for very simple touch nozzle bed homing. Furthermore printer maintenance is a lot easier, as it allows the x-axis to be lifted up by hand. This has been designed for use with a Bulldog Lite/XL Extruder and Hexagon Hotend, however it can be easily modded for other combinations Additionally we have added a simple RAMPS 1.4 holder with dual 40mm fan bracket to keep it very cool during operation. There are many other upgrades included, take a look through the pictures above to see them all. We have created full build documentation, parts list, and pre-configured marlin firmware so you can get up and running as quick as possible. This can all be found under the documentation tab above. We hope you like the printer! To buy a full kit for this printer see our website: http://ooznest.co.uk/Prusa-i3-Kit

Full Instruction Manual: http://www.ooznest.co.uk/Prusa/Prusa-Instructions-v1.40.pdf Parts List: http://www.ooznest.co.uk/Prusa/Parts-List.pdf Marlin Firmware: http://www.ooznest.co.uk/Prusa/Marlin.zip Cura Profile: http://www.ooznest.co.uk/Prusa/Marlin.zip Example G-Code Print (ABS): http://www.ooznest.co.uk/Prusa/CuteOcto.zip

comments.author: JamesPurcell

comments.text: Hello, on the left z-axis isolator there is a slot for a mechanical endstop (The ones with a PCB Board) this isolator moves the z-axis up and down. When auto bed levelling the z-axis goes down and the tip of the nozzle touches the bed and stops, however the z-axis isolators carrying on going down, this release the mechanical endstop. Apply an offset in the firmware and then the printer knows when the bed is. I will probably upload a video of it in action soon.

This is a derivative of emmett's wonderful heart gears. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6291 Same gears, but all of the gears are on one square plate, and can be scaled to print on a cupcake all at once! How small can it go? lets find out!

The file contains original sized gears. If you have access to a printer with a large build platform this could be handy.  Before printing,  if scaled to 0.75  it will just barely fit on a cupcake bed. Make sure your platform is very centered (as you can see from the photos, watch your raft size!). the gears themselves are parametric, but for this method you will likely have to drill the holes to-size for whatever teeny screws you have around. 
I normally do not print with a raft, but was having trouble getting the bottom right mini gear to stick. YMMV
This plate printed in 1hr on my cupcake. 1hr20m w/raft. @0.2 infill. The large heart is 6+ hours, as well as 9 start/stops. 
The pictures show my trial run, with a slightly less than optimal arrangement. I have included a second, better, arrangement.  but have not printed them yet.  I made a point to take advantage of sneaking things off ledges, and under overhangs etc. so they can be scaled as large as possible, but still fit the platform.

description.text:
A simple Spice Rack Carousel for the kitchen. Print One Carousel Base and One Carousel Tray Top. Then print as many Carousel Tray Middles as needed. I'm sure there is a height limit that you can get to before it tries to tip over but it should work for at least two Middle Trays. There is 11 Holes per tray so you could potentially hold 11 if only printing the base and Top to 33 Spice containers if you print two middle trays and one top. It also may help to put some rubber grip or some grip tape on the Carousel Base to keep in from sliding. The trays and the Top should then rotate freely on each other  
I have not tested this yet so the Holes for the spices to sit into may be really loose or tight. I designed the holes to be 2" in diameter. I believe the spice containers you get from the grocery store are 1 1/2"-1 3/4" in diameter so they should fit inside the holes. This is mainly designed for the Short Spice containers but could fit the taller ones on the top tray.  
The 11 Count isn't small enough for the Makerbot Replicator to build. The 4 Count and 6 Count trays are though. Thy reuse the Base and also can be mix and matched together.

My rc eye one xtreme crashed because of a broken arm.
Most of the wobbly plastic parts were broken.
Therefore i decided to create my own frame and reuse the motors, electronics and lipo. This is the improved light version of the frame. It flies very good and has a keycam. The weight is ca. 55g more than the original frame.
Improvement April, 29. 2015:
I made the lighter parts and reduced the weight for ca. 25g.
Now it flies better as before and very stable.
The total weight with cam (without LIPO) is now 231g.
Use the newer files with "...light...stl". Have fun!

I printed with 0.2mm resolution.
Brim at the arms.
Support 5% with top and bottom.
Motor cable is long enough and slips very good into the arm.
Use M3x25 screws for top to bottom.
Front LED has to be shortened.
Use original rubber-spacer and screws for fixing the mainboard.
Don't forget to put the foam on the barometric sensor. Good luck!
Some cheap doors are empty inside so just cutting a hole is not so pretty! With this thing, the hole is much cleaner and the cat has access to it's litter.

title: Wanhao Duplicator Hi Capacity Fan Bracket

description.text:
This is a pair of laser cut parts (spacer and bracket) to adapt a Hi Flow fan to a Wanhao Duplicator. The fan duct http://www.thingiverse.com/make:117375 utilises a std 40mm fan and since finding a fan GUB0412VHF in my “junk” box which measures 40 x 50mm an adapter was called for! Some M3 hole tapping and countersinking is needed. The spacer is 6mm thick and the bracket 3mm thick. The performance has improved markedly with a noticeable increase in “wind chill”
The fan utilises 2 counter rotating impellers and is not as noisy as I had anticipated. The fan would hit the door of the printer if left in place so it was removed (QD hinge pins) and there is plenty of clearance when the machine is zeroing though I would suggest being careful during commissioning trials. Print quality has just jumped up a notch and printing overhangs is much much better than before. The fan is 12v per motor so it can be rewired in series to adapt to the Wanhao 24v output.

This is a model of an interactive instrument I'm creating.
This model contains pieces of 2.5 mm cardboard lasercutted and assembled in pressure fit.
At bottom I fitted the form of a loudspeaker using 6 circles.

To push together all pieces, follow this order:
On the hexagon base (hole in the center) join 4 corner pieces and the 3 sides between.
Then join all circles. Now join out of base the 2 corner and 3 sides left.
Then press this group of pieces all together on the base, joining the outer sides of each group too.
At last press the top hexagon to the body fastening it with 18 friction points.

description.text:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2205631 Want some freshly squeezed orange juice or do you want some lime in your favorite soda drink?
Use this citrus juicer to make your drink! You can screw this juicer on top of almost any bottle and when you squeeze your orange the juice flows right in the bottle. The holes where it has to go through make sure no pulp will ruin your drink. You then have your fresh orange juice directly in the bottle. The prints are test fitted on bottles from the following countries:
  • The Netherlands
  • Germany
  • Norway
  • Czech Republic
  • Belgium
  • Sweden
  • Norwegian
    • Please leave a comment, make or personal message when you printed the juicer and let others know if it fits on the bottles used in your country! (I think it fits almost every bottle) (13-Mar-2015 ) UPDATE: There is now also a version with bigger holes available for download. Now you can also enjoy your drinks with pulp.
    (30-Mar-2017) UPDATE: A complete new version has been uploaded. This thing is now outdated and I advise to print the newest version.

title: Auto bed leveling using piezo discs

description.text:
Auto Bed Leveling using piezo electric discs for very high sensitivity. Update v 0.2! Now using a single piezo disc glued (temporarily at least) to the x-carriage (see image). With the piezo element glued between the two bearings gliding on the x-axis shafts, and tiny amount of twisting (like the hotend touching the bed) will ever so slightly bend the plastic in the x-carriage. Since the piezo is glued on top, this will bend as well creating a relatively large signal. Thus even a minuscule force acting upon the hot-end can be detected using some electronics. This solves the problem of the previous setup with differing sensitivity of the three piezo discs (due to the discs them self and/or the mechanical setup) in v 0.1. Auto leveling is now even better, giving a perfect first layer every time (as long as the nozzle has been wiped clean of plastic, that is). New video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LWRq2t9Pr-E
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0oBzWWZYKgE Still to do: Electronics is rather sensitive to EMI, so I'm waiting for a metal case for it. Right now, it can trigger when probing too close to the x-axis stepper if it's moving, so a quick fix right now has been to add a pause (in firmware) after moving to the right x-y position before starting the z movement. Old v 0.1 info:
Mounted between the bed springs and the z-stage, any force down on the bed can be registered and used as a probe signal. Hence one can measure when the hot-end touches the bed surface. No modification to the hot-end or carriage is therefore needed, and the probe is insensitive to temperature. This is still a work in progress, so although it is working for me in it's current form, it needs constant tuning as the circuit is not yet perfected, and the mechanical mounts have some known issues. A new circuit and new mounts have been designed but not yet tested. So far, I've tried to only use parts available from sparkfun. I'm guessing a total cost for all parts of less than $20 USD. Video of version 0.1 doing bed height mapping : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zn9X-WGBuvQ Discussion at soliforum:
http://www.soliforum.com/post/88147

Print the v0.3 back, and two v0.3 fronts, one of the mirrored. Drill the smaller hole out to 3 mm, and the larger one to 4.5mm. Glue the piezo disc underneath using silicone glue. Use an m4 screw to center the lever on the holes in the bed-holder, and drill through the 3mm into the aluminium, so that you can use some m3 screws to fasten the levers to the bed-holder. The rest of the mounting should be self explanatory. Since the sensors are very sensitive, the acceleration of the z-axis and the intertia of the bed can be enough to trigger the probe. It can therefore be helpful to disable z-jerk and decrease z acceleration. With repetier firmware, there's a seperate travel acceleration setting, so this is the script I use: G0 Z10; goto 10mm z height to prevent crashing in bed
M202 Z30; set z acceleration
M207 Z0; disable z-jerk
G32 S0; auto level
M207 Z5; restore z-jerk
M202 Z300; restore z acceleration

comments.text: Because my bed moves in the Z-direction, so when it starts to move it vibrates. This would trigger the circuit. Also, it should work better at low speeds (more accurate) than impact, which would probably need higher speeds. The impact should be close to a DC signal plus some slight ringing. The DC signal would be stronger and easier to filter out.

comments.text: AD822 is a rail-to-rail op-amp, so it can output 0-5 V with a 5V supply, whereas the LM358 can only output 0-3.5 V. So it makes the allowable voltage swing a bit tighter.

comments.text: Not a stupid question. The reason I went for the transimpedance amplifier is so you can wire a whole bunch of piezo's in parallel, and not need a dedicated circuit for each one. With a normal voltage amplifier, the signal would get weaker for each piezo in parallel.
comments.author: inornate

comments.text: Ah it was stupid question. Picture has the answer. It's parallel.
comments.author: inornate

comments.text: Added a new circuit I tested yesterday, with great success. Uses two dual op-amps. One as a buffer for single supply power, one transimpedance amplifier so stray capacitance and capacitance in wires can be ignored, one integrator (with very aggressive low pass filtering) and the last one for thresholding. Schottky diodes added to protect circuit from sudden voltage spikes, especially important when the unit is turned off and something is dropped on the build plate.

author: bitswype

title: FIXED: SDS Drill Bit Holder - Parametric (& OpenSCAD functions)

description.text:
I had a few long SDS* drill bits rattling around.
So I made a holder. It is for 10mm shank SDS and for 12mm, 16mm & 24mm bits, but it's parametric so you can make your own. FIXED See SDS Holder v5.scad - Now works for bit sizes smaller than shank size too. Also introduced a couple of extra functions, in VectorMath v2.scad. To do this I needed some creative maths. I came up with min/max/sum functions for a vector. In case they are useful I have included VectorMath.scad which you can use as a library. NOTE: The sumv() second parameter is not optional, it must be the n-1'st last element to sum, so if you want to total use len(v)-1. I have updated VectorMath.scad * Wikipedia "Developed by Bosch in 1975 for hammer drills, the SDS System uses an SDS Shank which is a cylindrical shank with indentations to be held by the chuck. A tool is inserted into the chuck by pressing in, and is locked in place until a separate lock release is used."

You can include a vector of bit sizes and it produces one end for the SDS Shank, and another for the particular bit sizes (remember to measure including the carbide tip).  I suggest the two larger sized bits go at each end.  
Optionally include a hole for a bungie cord hook to clip them together, or a different hook, the squarish one (not printed yet), for an elastic band etc, this has a small support tab which needs to be removed.  
I have issues with inside circles being too tight, so I have the tolerance variable, adjust to suit your printer/software. Do a test with one 10mm bit to save plastic.  
Suits thick layers; perimiters/infill depends on how roughly you are going to treat them.

comments.text: PS. The built-in min() and max() functions can now take vector parameters

author: bitswype

title: Modular carriage & nozzle plugs for prusa i3

description.text:
This is a modular carriage to host a 40x40 nozzle fan and a 51x51x15 blower fan to cool PLA. It carries "plugs" designed to securely host jheads without requiring much mechanical work and calibration at each change.
Electrical connection modularity will be next step. I designed plugs for j-head bowden, j-head direct drive, Immaginaecrea.it hotend in bowden mode (it originally mounts a 60mmx15x15 alluminium profile for cooling). Among the advantages I see:
  • good nozzle cold end cooling
  • the blower mount and duct (if you choose e good blower you're fine, avoid low cost ones... but befare of noise of good ones!)
  • the very low profile (allow to max print height to 190)
  • the mount to x carriage which is standard 50mm spacing with 2xM3 screws.
    • You'll need:
  • 2x M4x20 screws and 2 M4 nuts, for the plug locker
  • 2x M3x40 screws and 2 M3 nuts, to mount it to the carriage
  • 4x M3x20 screws and 4 M4 nuts, to mount the fans.

title: E3D v6 hot-end mod for Da Vinci 1.0

description.text: This is a remix of thing:608560, which works quite well but in my opinnion it could do with a more sturdy assembly, for improved stability of the hot-end and the carriage itself. I've modified the lower part and the spacer (which comes from the original v2 design). The upper part and the drilling template are the same models that can be found in the original v1 mod. Update (20150512): I've created a custom layer cooling fan duct to go with this mod: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:822476

Bill of materials:
  • E3Dv6 1.75mm Universal (Direct or Bowden), or the new Lite6 version.
  • 2 x 30mm M3 screws (35mm would also work, I think) and optionally a few washers.
    • You want the upper and lower parts to be as sturdy as possible, so don't be cheap with the infill, use 50% or higher. Use the drilling template to drill the holes in the carriage that allow raising the stepper. This will require removing the X carriage, for which you'll also need to detach the left Y carriage from its rod (just pull from it to detach the bronze bushings). Then unscrew the stepper motor from the carriage, place the drilling template lined up with the existing holes and drill the 3 missing ones. Finally, use a utility knife or something similar to make a semi-circular cut into the plastic of the carriage, as shown in the picture of thing:608560. This is required for the stepper to fit on its new position. To reduce the friction at the pivot of the metal bracket that holds the idler wheel, I suggest you add a washer like on my picture (I just super-glued it to the plastic). Assemble everything back tightly and make sure the stepper's gear is well lined up with the throat of the E3D. Depending on your printer's accuracy you might need to sand or shim the lower part for this. The short PTFE tube going down to the gear that you can see in the pictures is optional but highly recommended to facilitate the loading of filament. To install this I used a solder iron to soften and widen the tube and then applied super-glue. The breakout PCB board may be attached in different ways. Mine is simply zip tied for now but I'm working on another piece to do this better.
  • Update (20150405): A little while ago I designed a custom holder for the breakout PCB, which is nicer than having it just zip tied. I've uploaded the model, which could be easily extended to even make use of the filament sensor, should anyone ever want to do that. However, as of today I've just gotten rid of this PCB -since it's not actually necessary- and made straight connections for the fan and the thermistor using quick release connectors. See the pictures with and without it.
    Read the volvivo thread below (page 4) to find out the wire mapping (warning: the 1.0 and the 1.0A use different wires and/or colors for each thing!)
    • You may find more details about installing this mod in this thread over at the Voltivo forum Also check out this amazingly detailed step by step installation guide in youtube that someone has made!

comments.text: Be careful with the board holder. When you slide the board in it shears off the component at U1. The return flange is too long.

comments.text: Maybe. It's just I'm trying to print PLA for the first time and couldn't get all the way through a Benchy without the filament swelling in the tube badly enough that it wouldn't extrude anymore. For now I've stuck to using hairspray for adhesion rather than the recommended 60C on the heated bed, and leaving the chamber door open, and it's been better, but it's just a bit odd, since everywhere I read people say a heated glass bed is ideal for PLA adhesion, yet it seems to have been a significant factor in causing the failure to begin with. I figured maybe a better fan setup on the hot end's heatsink might alleviate the issue, but I think I'll look at printing/building two of those fan setups that fit in the slots on either side of the build chamber in a push/pull configuration.

comments.text: Nope, sorry, you'll need to do just a bit of drilling unfortunately. It's extremely easy though, but you'll need to take apart the entire carriage for it (well technically maybe not but it'd be difficult to do it with the carriage in place). Check the Voltivo thread linked, it has some more pictures of the installation. Also I've updated the instructions tab with a bit more detailed... instructions :)

This is a basic Point of Balance stand for displaying a sword. Please note that this will only work on properly balanced swords. This is a modification of Avioza's Mordern Pillar: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:529699

Print with 20% infill. Scale to proportions to the sword you want to display/blade thickness. Be default this stand will fit most swords/blade widths, and is tall enough to properly display most swords with medium crossguards.  
I suggest gluing a piece of no-slip material to the bottom, and some soft felt on the inside.You can also paint with stoneware pattern spray paint.
